poem_title: VERSES to WILLIAM SHENSTONE, Esq; On receiving a Gilt Pocket-Book. 1751.
author: Richard Jago

lines.line_text: THESE spotless leaves, this neat array
Might  invite your charming quill,
In fair assemblage to display
The power of learning, wit, and skill:

stanzas.stanza_text:
THESE spotless leaves, this neat array
Might  invite your charming quill,
In fair assemblage to display
The power of learning, wit, and skill:

lines.line_text: But since  carelessly refuse,
And to my pen the task assign;
O! let your Genius guide my Muse,
And every vulgar thought refine.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But since  carelessly refuse,
And to my pen the task assign;
O! let your Genius guide my Muse,
And every vulgar thought refine.

lines.line_text: Teach me your best, your best-lov'd art,
With frugal care to store my mind;
In  to play the miser's part,
And give mean lucre to the wind:

stanzas.stanza_text:
Teach me your best, your best-lov'd art,
With frugal care to store my mind;
In  to play the miser's part,
And give mean lucre to the wind:

lines.line_text: To shun the coxcomb's empty noise;
To scorn the villain's artful mask;
Nor trust gay pleasure's fleeting joys,
Nor urge ambition's endless task.
Teach me to stem youth's boisterous tide;
To regulate its giddy rage;
By reason's aid, my barque to guide
Into the friendly port of age:
To share what  culture yields;
Thro'  painted meads to roam;
With you to reap historic fields,
And bring the golden harvest
To taste the genuine sweets of
To quaff in  sprightly bowl;
The philosophic  to hit,
And prize the dignity of soul.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To taste the genuine sweets of
To quaff in  sprightly bowl;
The philosophic  to hit,
And prize the dignity of soul.

lines.line_text: Teach me to read fair  book,
Wide-opening in each flowery plain;
And with judicious eye to look
On all the glories of her reign.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Teach me to read fair  book,
Wide-opening in each flowery plain;
And with judicious eye to look
On all the glories of her reign.

lines.line_text: To hail her seated on her throne;
By aweful woods encompass'd round:
Or her  extraction own,
Tho' with a wreath of rushes crown'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To hail her seated on her throne;
By aweful woods encompass'd round:
Or her  extraction own,
Tho' with a wreath of rushes crown'd.

lines.line_text: Thro' arched walks, o'er spreading lawns,
Near solemn rocks, with  to rove:
Or court her, 'mid her gentle fauns,
In mossy cell, or maple grove.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Thro' arched walks, o'er spreading lawns,
Near solemn rocks, with  to rove:
Or court her, 'mid her gentle fauns,
In mossy cell, or maple grove.

lines.line_text: Whether the prospect strain the sight,
Or in the nearer landskips charm,
Where hills, vales, fountains, woods unite.
To grace our sweet  farm,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Whether the prospect strain the sight,
Or in the nearer landskips charm,
Where hills, vales, fountains, woods unite.
To grace our sweet  farm,

lines.line_text: let me sit; and gaze with you,
On Nature's works by Art refin'd;
And own, while we their contest view,
Both fair, but fairest,  combin'd!
